etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Chemical News. From fluoro- + -anth- + -ene, after German Fluoranthen, so named in account of its fluorescence in ultraviolet light

definitions: An aromatic hydrocarbon which crystallizes as colourless needles or plates, found in coal tar and as a product of combustion.

notes.text: Formula: C₁₆H₁₀. Fluoranthene contains benzene and naphthalene rings linked directly by two bonds to form a central five-membered ring.
